item.title: Zero to One: Notes on Start Ups, or How to Build the Future - Blake Masters, Peter Thiel
item.dc:creator: enrico468red@gmail.com
item.content:encoded:
1. Make incremental advances
  2. stay lean and flexible. All companies must be “lean”, which is code for “unplanned” yeapharmacy.com. You should not know what your business will do; planning is arrogant and inflexible. Instead you should try things out, “iterate” and treat entrepreneurship as agnostic experimentation.
  3. improve on competition. Don’t try to create a new market prematurely
  4. Focus on product, not sales
  5. if you can recognize competition as a destructive force instead of a sign of value, you are already more sane than most.
  6. Characteristics of monopoly:
    • proprietary technology
    • network effects. Paradoxically, then, network effects business must start especially small markets. Facebook started with just Harvard students.
    • economies of scale
    • branding. Beginning with brand rather substance is dangerous.
  7. start small and monopolize. Therefore, every startup should start with a very small market. It is easier to domincate a small market than a large one. The perfect target market for a startup is a small group of particular people concentrated together and served by few or no competitors. Any big market is a bad choice.
  8. Scaling up once you create and dominate a niche market, then you should gradually expand into related and slightly broader markets.
  9. The most successful companies make the core progression, to first dominate a specific niche and then scale to adjacent markets.
  10. Don’t disrupt, es. Paypal and credit cards. As you craft a plan to expand to adjacent markets, don’t disrupt: avoid competition as much as possible.
  11. Jobs saw that you can change the world through careful planning, not by listening to focus group feedback or copying others’ successes
  12. you should focus relentlessly on something you are good at doing, but before that you must think hard about whether it will be valuable in the future
  13. As a founder, your first job is to get the first things right, because you cannot build a great company on a flawed foundation
  14. Part-time employees don’t work. Even working remotely should be avoided, because misalignment can creep in whenever colleagues aren’t together full-time, in the same place, every day.
  15. A company does better the less it pays the CEO.
  16. A cash bonus is slightly better than a cash salary, at least it’s contingent on a job well done. But even so-called incentive pay encourages short-term thinking and value grabbing.  Any kind of cash is more about the present than the future. Equity can’t create perfect incentives, but it is the best way a founder to keep everyone in the company broadly aligned.
  17. Recruiting is a core competency for any company. It should never be outsourced.
  18. You will attract the employees you need if you can explain why your mission is compelling: not why it is important in general, but why you are doing something important that no one else is going to get done. Just cover the basics like health insurance and then promise what no others can: the opportunity to do irreplaceable work on a unique problem alongside great people.
  19. The best thing I did a manager at PayPal was to make every person in the company responsible for doing just one thing. Defining roles reduced conflict.
  20. A product is viral if its core functionality encourages users to invite their friends to become users.
  21. Seven questions that every business must answer:
    1. the engineering question. Can you create breakthrough technology instead of incremental improvements?
    2. The timing questions. Is now the right time to start your particular business?
    3. The monopoly question. Are you starting with a big share of a small market?
    4. The people questions. Do you have the right team?
    5. The distribution question. Do you have a way to not just create but deliver your product?
    6. The durability question. Will your market position be defensible 10 and 20 years into the future?
    7. the secret question. Have you identified a unique opportunity that others don’t see?
  22. you can’t dominate a submarket if it’s fictional, and huge markets are highly competitive, not highly attainable.
  23. Never invest in a tech CEO that wears a suit.
  24. Every entrepreneur should plan to be the last mover in her particular market.
  25. A valuable business must start by finding a niche and dominating a small market.

item.title: Sample Page
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

1. The genesis of great companies is answering simple questions that change the world, not the desire to become rich.
  2. Cofounding soul mates need to have both similarities and differences.

  6. DO NOT ADD FOUNDERS TO ENHANCE FUNDABILITY
  7. ASSUME THE BEST, BUT PLAN FOR THE WORST

  9. Make Mantra:
    1. BREVITY
    2. POSITIVITY. Mantras are uplifting and explain how your startup does good things that make the world a better place
    3. OUTWARD FOCUS. Mantras express what you do for customers and society
  10. Pick a Business Model:
    1. You’ll tweak your business model constantly—in
    2. TARGET A SPECIFIC NICHE
    3. KEEP IT SIMPLE. If you can’t describe your business model in ten words or fewer, you don’t have a business model.
  11. The five most important milestones are: Working prototype Initial capital Field-testable version Paying customer Cash-flow breakeven. Discussing and documenting these assumptions at an early stage is important because they are a reality check on the viability of a startup.
  12. Keep Things Clean and Simple
  13. If you are not embarrassed by the first version of your product, you’ve launched too late
  14. pretenders. These questions will help you identify good advisers, board members, and investors

  17. Can we get a bank loan to start our business? Answer you’re looking for: “No”
  18. you don’t want money from investors who do believe your projections, because they are clueless
  19. You shouldn’t write a business plan. You should get customers.
  20. A real business is one with something to sell—not one where people have business cards and letterhead
  21. The best brands never start out with the intent of building a great brand. They focus on building a great—and profitable—product or service and an organization that can sustain it.
  22. Elegance is the combination of power and simplicity
  23. PICK A NAME WITH “VERB POTENTIAL
  24. check the meaning of your names in other languages
  25. PICK A WORD THAT BEGINS WITH A LETTER EARLY IN THE ALPHABET
  26. The goal of the MVP is to begin the process, not end it
  27. Holding yourself to a mass-scaling test in the early days is a mistake—putting. Your priority, in short, is proving that people will use your product at all. If they won’t, then it won’t matter if you can’t scale. If they will, then you will figure out a way to.
  28. CREATE ONE MESSAGE.  Pick one message and stick with it for at least six months to see what happens.
  29. Do you describe your offering in a way that is opposite to that of your competition?
  30. FOCUS ON SOCIAL MEDIA, NOT ADVERTISING
  31. ABANDON THE ILLUSION OF CONTROL
  32. PLANT MANY SEEDS
  33. Tell a Story. They want faith—faith in you, your product, your success, and in the story you tell. Faith, not facts, moves mountains. Meaningful stories inspire faith in you and your product.
  34. don’t limit yourself to online comments and cumulative reports. Go and see for yourself how people are using them.
  35. concept of premortems, coined by Gary Klein, chief scientist of Klein Associates and author of Sources of Power: How People Make Decisions. Write a list of at least ten factors that could kill your launch. How many can you eliminate?
  36. during a presentation/pitch:
    1. BRING TWO OF EVERYTHING
    2. GET ORGANIZED IN ADVANCE
    3. ELIMINATE THE FACTORS THAT YOU CAN’T CONTROL
    4. START WITH “SHOCK AND AWE”
    5. CUT THE JOKES
    6. DO IT ALONE
    7. CUT THE JARGON
    8. DON’T TAKE ANY QUESTIONS UNTIL THE END
    9. END WITH AN EXCLAMATION POINT
    10. one more thing...like Steve Jobs
  37. PUT THE COMPANY FIRST
  38. STAY UNDER THE RADAR
  39. Effective intrapreneurs anticipate these shifts
  40. COLLECT AND SHARE DATA. Prepare for that day by (1) collecting data about how much you’ve spent and how much you’ve accomplished, and (2) then sharing it openly
  41. Be driven not by your importance but by the work that you’re trying to do
  42. Exude Optimism. Above all, leaders cannot have a bad day. No matter how scared and depressed you are, you cannot show fear, uncertainty, or doubt. You must exude optimism every day
  43. SET AND COMMUNICATE GOALS
  44. MEASURE PROGRESS
  45. In a startup, you should measure and report results every week. A person who knows he is being measured and held accountable is highly motivated to succeed
  46. BE PART OF THE SOLUTION
  47. REWARD THE ACHIEVERS
  48. If you are serious about staying in touch with reality, these are the ten most important questions you can ask: What is our top priority? When will we ship? When will we run out of money if we don’t ship? How much does it cost to acquire a customer? What is our true, fully loaded cost of operations? Whom do we compete with? What can our competition do that we can’t? Who are our nonperforming employees? What can we beg, borrow, or lease that we are buying? How good am I as a leader?

    3. This person is the yang to the CEO’s yin. The CEO decides “what,” while the Morpheus asks “what could go wrong?” Their relationship is not an opposition but a counterbalance

  52. The self-confidence to recruit these “better than me” people
  53. Startups need people with diverse skills that complement, not overlap, each other
  54. Make People Better. You hire minimum viable people, and much like improving your minimum viable product, you improve your minimum viable employee

  56. Address Your Shortcomings First
  57. Don’t Ask Employees to Do What You Wouldn’t Do

  59. Celebrating the incremental successes of an organization is a powerful way to motivate employee, particularly if you emphasize team wins rather than individual ones.

  61. Tell Employees That They’re Wanted
  62. Once you’ve decided to hire someone, turn on the charm: communicate that you want her, invite her to come by the office, have other employees take her out for drinks, and ask her for input

  65. Focus instead on affordability—that is, inexperienced young people with bushels of talent, energy, and curiosity

    3. pick the gold standard in your industry and identify an important point of differentiation in your own product, such as: Cost Ease of use Convenience Industrial design Reliability Speed/performance Range of selection Customer service Geographic location
  70. take care of the small stuff in rapid, good enough—not perfect—ways
  71. If you want to bootstrap your organization, then understaff it
  72. Outsourcing strategic functions such as research and development, marketing, and sales is riskier. Candidates for outsourcing include: Customer service Tech support Accounting Facilities management

  75. Here are the key tips for succeeding in crowdfunding:

    5. SHOW A BUDGET
  76. you need an introduction by a credible person to get a decision maker to take a serious look at your startup by investors
  77. Acknowledge, or Create, an Enemy

  84. The best protection of an idea is great implementation of the idea.
  85. Focus on building your business, not finding the best deal. In the long run, the quality of your business determines how much money you’ll make, not the deal you cut years before with an investor.
  86. During a pitch:
    1. be Prepared: get there early and set the stage. Bring your own projector. Bring two laptops loaded up with your presentation. Bring two VGA adapters. Bring a copy of your presentation on a USB drive. Bring printouts of your presentation in case nothing works
    2. Set the Stage
    3. “How much of your time do I have?”
    4. “What are the three most important pieces of information that I can provide?”
    5. “May I quickly go through my presentation and handle questions at the end?”
    6. The purpose of a pitch is to stimulate interest, not to cover every aspect of your startup and bludgeon your audience into submission
    7. Ten Slides are:
        1. TITLE
        2. PROBLEM AND OPPORTUNITY
        3. VALUE PROPOSITION. Explain how you alleviate pain and the meaning that you make. This is not the place for an in-depth technical explanation
        4. UNDERLYING MAGIC. Describe the technology, secret sauce, or magic behind your product. The less text and the more diagrams, schematics, and flowcharts the better
        5. BUSINESS MODEL. Explain how you make money: who pays you, your channels of distribution, and your gross margins.
        6. GO-TO-MARKET PLAN. Explain how you are going to reach your customer and summarize your marketing leverage points
        7. COMPETITIVE ANALYSIS. Provide a complete view of the competitive landscape
        8. MANAGEMENT TEAM. Describe the key players of your management team,
        9. FINANCIAL PROJECTIONS AND KEY METRICS. Provide a three-to-five-year forecast containing not only dollars but also key metrics, such as number of customers and conversion rate
        10. CURRENT STATUS, ACCOMPLISHMENTS TO DATE, TIMELINE, AND USE OF FUNDS. Explain the current status of your product
    8. Twenty Minutes. Thirty-Point Font. slides are to lead, not read. NEVER. READ. YOUR. SLIDES. USE A DARK BACKGROUND. ADD YOUR LOGO TO THE MASTER PAGE. USE COMMON, SANS-SERIF FONTS. ANIMATE YOUR BODY, NOT YOUR SLIDES. Each slide should communicate one point
    9. BUILD BULLETS. Build your bullets: click, bullet one, explain; click, bullet two, explain;USE ONLY ONE LEVEL OF BULLETS
    10. USE DIAGRAMS AND GRAPHS. MAKE PRINTABLE SLIDES. Let One Person Do the Talking
    11. suppose someone wants to debate a multiple-tier distribution system for selling products. You raise a good point. Can we follow up with you on that?
    12. Pitch Constantly. Twenty-five repetitions
    13. investors are not looking for detailed forecasts containing every conceivable line item. They’re looking for the big picture and trying to understand the kinds of assumptions that you’re making about your business.
    14. Shut Up, Take Notes, Summarize, Regurgitate, and Follow Up. The visible act of taking notes says, ‘I think you’re smart
    15. START STRONG. CUT THE INDUSTRY JARGON. DROP ALL THE BIG NAMES YOU CAN. CATALYZE FANTASY. FINISH STRONG
  87. The Art of Building a Team:
    1. Ignore the Irrelevant (gender, race…);
    2. focus on these three factors: Can the candidate do what you need? Does the candidate believe in what you’re doing? Is the candidate likeable and trustworthy?
    3. Dramatize Your Expectations Make it clear to anyone you hire that working in a startup is different from what they are used to
    4. Here’s a procedure to help you make good decisions:
        1. STRUCTURE THE INTERVIEWS
        2. ASK ABOUT SPECIFIC JOB SITUATIONS
        3. STICK TO THE SCRIPT. Minimize spontaneous questions. You want to get a sample of candidates who answered the same questions in order to accurately compare them
        4. CONDUCT INITIAL INTERVIEWS BY PHONE
        5. DON’T GET TOO TOUCHY-FEELY
        6. What are the accomplishments you’re most proud of?” “What were your biggest failures?” “What was your most gratifying learning experience?” Again, worry about competence first
        7. MATCH THE PERSON AND THE POSITION
        8. TAKE NOTES
        9. CHECK REFERENCES EARLY
        10. You should use reference checking as a means to decide whether the candidate is good, and not as a confirmation of a choice that you’ve already made
        11. Use All Your Tools (Linkedin…)
    5. YOUR VISION. For many people, money isn’t the most important motivational factor. They will work for less to do more by making meaning and changing the world.
    6. YOUR TEAM. Life is too short to work with people you don’t like—especially in a startup. Define an Initial Review Period

  89. you need to create or find a product that rolls the DICEE:
    1. DEEP
    2. INTELLIGENT. An intelligent product reflects your insights on how to ease people’s pain or increase their pleasure
    3. COMPLETE. A complete product embodies everything a customer needs, such as support, documentation, and enhancements
    4. EMPOWERING. An empowering product makes people better.
    5. ELEGANT
  90. Put the Best Interests of Others at Heart
  91. Achieve Humanness
  92. TARGET THE YOUNG
  93. MAKE FUN OF YOURSELF. HAVE FUN TOO
  94. FEATURE YOUR CUSTOMERS
  95. HELP THE UNDERSERVED AND UNDERPRIVILEGED
  96. Make It Personal
  97. It’s not what you know or who you know, but who knows you. —Susan RoAne
  98. No one is more fascinating than a good listener.
  99. GET OUT. ASK GOOD QUESTIONS; THEN SHUT UP. MAKE IT EASY TO GET IN TOUCH. FOLLOW UP. UNVEIL YOUR PASSIONS. GIVE FAVORS.
  100. Learn How to Use E-mail:
    1. OPTIMIZE YOUR SUBJECT LINE
    2. TIME IT FOR TUESDAY
    3. KEEP IT SHORT AND SIMPLE
  101. Create a Program
  102. HAVE SOMETHING INTERESTING TO SAY
  103. REMOVE THE SALES PITCH. The purpose of most keynotes is to entertain and inform the audience
  104. CUSTOMIZE
  105. FOCUS ON ENTERTAINING
  106. DON’T DENIGRATE THE COMPETITION
  107. TELL STORIES
  108. PRECIRCULATE WITH THE AUDIENCE
  109. SPEAK AT THE START OF AN EVENT
  110. ASK FOR A SMALL ROOM
  111. PRACTICE AND SPEAK ALL THE Time
  112. What’s more important than planning is grinding—that is, working long and hard and experimenting. In other words, social media is like everything else you’re doing!
  113. Pretend that every single person you meet has a sign around his or her neck that says, “Make me feel important.” Not only will you succeed in sales, you will succeed in life
  114. When flowers are blossoming, your task is to determine where and why they are blossoming and then adjust your business to reap your good fortune
  115. See the Gorilla

  117. To make your startup last, don’t depende on the people at the top
  118. The middles and bottoms are the key constituencies to foster endurance
  119. if you started a great company, you won’t need to use money, and bringing money into the picture may undermine your efforts.

    1. give early. Do favors before you need favors back
    2. give with joy
    3. give often and generously
    4. give unexpectedly
    5. tell people how they can pay you back
  121. Implementation supersedes policy and delights the customer. Under promise and over deliver for great support

item.content:encoded:
1. The power of intuition enables us to size up a situation quickly. The power of mental simulation lets us imagine how a course of action might be carried out. The power of metaphor lets us draw on our experience by suggesting parallels between the current situation and something else we have come across. The power of storytelling helps us consolidate our experiences to make them available in the future, either to ourselves or to others
  2. to be a good fireground commander, you need to have a rich fantasy life.
  3. mental simulation is the ability to imagine people and objects consciously and to transform those people and objects through several transactions, finally picturing them in a different way than at the start.
  4. without a sufficient amount of expertise and background knowledge, edge, it may be difficult or impossible to build a mental simulation
  5. stories organize events into a meaningful framework
  6. Considerations in communicating intent:
    1. the purpose of the task (the higher level goals)
    2. the objective of the task (an imagine of the desidered outcome)
    3. the sequence of steps in the plan

The Ten Principles of Abundance Thinking
  1. If it’s digital, sooner or later it’s going to be free.
  2. Atoms would like to be free, too, but they’re not so pushy about it.
  3. You can’t stop free.
  4. You can make money from free.
People will pay to save time. People will pay to lower risk. People will pay for things they love. People will pay for status. People will pay if you make them (once they‘re hooked). There are countless ways to make money around free (I list fifty of them at the end of the book). free opens doors, reaching new consumers. It doesn‘t mean you can‘t charge some of them.
  1. Redefine your market.
Ryanair‘s competitors were in the airline seat business. It decided to be in the travel business instead.
  1. Round down.
If the cost of something is heading to zero, free is just a matter of when, not if. Why not get there first, before someone else does? The first to free gets attention, and there are always ways to turn that into money. What can you make free today?
  1. Sooner or later you will compete with free.
Whether through cross-subsidies or software, somebody in your business is going to find a way to give away what you charge for.
  1. Embrace waste.
If something is becoming too cheap to meter, stop metering it.
  1. free makes other things more valuable.
Every abundance creates a new scarcity. A hundred years ago entertainment was scarce and time plentiful; now it‘s the reverse. When one product or service becomes free, value migrates to the next higher layer. Go there.
  1. Manage for abundance, not scarcity.
Where resources are scarce, they are also expensive—you have to be careful how you use them.

item.title: La vérité sur ce qui nous motive: Tout ce qu'il faut savoir pour transformer sa vie et aller de l'avant! - Daniel H. Pink

1. Quand l'argent est utilisé comme récompense extérieure d'une activité, le sujet attache moins d'intérêt à cette activité même.
  2. Si vous avez besoin que je vous motive, je ne suis pas disposé à vous engager.
  3. Seule  la récompense conditionnelle (si tu fais ceci, tu obtiendras cela) a eu un effet négatif.
  4. Quand on réalise une oeuvre pour quelqu'un d'autre, cela devient plus un "travail" qu'un plaisir.
  5. Le problème, quand une récompense extrinsèque devient le seul objectif qui compte, est que certains vont choisir le chemin le plus court pour l'atteindre, quitte à s'affranchir de la morale.
  6. Un travail qui n'est pas naturellement intéressant peut devenir plus motivant lorsqu'ils fait d'un projet plus global.
  7. Expliquez pourquoi ce tract est si important et pourquoi il est vital pour votre association de l'envoyer maintenant à ses adhérents. Reconnaissez que la tache est ennuyeuse. Il s'agit bien évidemment de faire preuve d'empathie.
  8. Laissez vos collaborateurs travailler à leur façon. Privilégiez l'autonomie plutôt que le contrôle. Présentez clairement votre objectif, mais plutôt que de détailler la façon de l'atteindre laissez- leur la liberté de faire leur travaille à leur manière.
  9. Ce qui motive les gens de façon plus profonde: l'autonomie, la maîtrise des choses et l'identification avec l'objectif.
  10. Toute récompense extrinsèque doit être inattendue et offerte une fois le travail terminé. En d'autres termes, là ou une récompense conditionnelle serait une erreur, une récompense a posteriori peut très bien convenir
  11. Premièrement, envisagez des récompenses non matérielles. Les compliments et autres formes de feedback positif valent mieux que l'argent et les trophées. Deuxièmement, délivrez une information utile. Vos collaborateurs seront toujours désireux de savoir si leur travail porte ses fruits et s'il est apprécie.
  12. Selon la notion de besoins humains universels nous avons trois besoins psychologiques innés: être compétents, être autonomes et entretenir des liens. Quand ces besoins sont satisfaits, nous sommes motives, productifs et heureux.
  13. Les gens sont autonomes dans ces quatre domaines: ce qu'ils font, quand ils le font, comment ils le font, avec qui ils le font.
  14. Il est préférable qu'ils aient le contrôle de leurs taches, de leur temps, de leur technique et du choix de leurs coéquipiers.
  15. Les objectifs sont en termes de performance et en termes d'apprentissage.
  16. Le meilleur indice de réussite était la perseverance et la passion pour les objectifs à long terme.
  17. Le flow n’est pas un luxe mais une nécessité. Nous en avons besoin pour survivre. C’est l’oxygène de l’âme.
  18. Pour les enfants: complimentez l’effort et la méthode, et non l’intelligence. Complimentez de façon spécifique, en privé. Ne complimentez que lorsque vous avez une bonne raison de le faire.
